name: Saltwater (3% NaCl by mass)
description: Homogeneous aqueous solution of sodium chloride

effectOfDissolution.boilingPointElevationSource: van't Hoff factor calculation: ΔTb = i·Kb·m = 1.9 × 0.512 °C/m × 0.5291 m ≈ 0.5147°C. NaCl molar mass = 58.443 g/mol (Na: 22.990, Cl: 35.453). Molality = (30g / 58.443) / 0.970 kg = 0.5291 m

triplePoint.note: Approximation; actual value depends on solute concentration

criticalPoint.note: Nearly identical to pure water; dissolved ions have minimal effect

note: At standard conditions, saltwater only exists as liquid. Freezing/boiling involves phase separation.
educationalNotes: Demonstrates colligative properties - dissolved salt raises boiling point (+0.515°C for 3% NaCl via van't Hoff factor i=1.9) and lowers freezing point (-1.87°C). This is why ocean water (≈3.5% salt) doesn't freeze as easily as freshwater and why we add salt to icy roads in winter! Saltwater conducts electricity (electrolyte) while pure water doesn't - dissolved Na⁺ and Cl⁻ ions carry charge. Osmosis: cells in saltwater shrivel as water leaves to dilute the salty solution outside. KEY: NaCl dissociates into 2 ions, so i≈1.9 (not 1), making salt's effect on boiling/freezing points almost twice as strong as non-electrolytes like sugar!
